image.altText: A close up of Lidia speaking.

items.synopsis: Independent senator Lidia Thorpe is considering abstaining from voting on legislation to enable the Voice referendum in the Senate but has ruled out supporting the No campaign.

title.children: Lidia Thorpe to lodge human rights complaint against Greens, may abstain from vote on Voice

image.altText: A woman stands outside court speaking.

items.synopsis: The Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions spent more than $260,000 on court proceedings against NT Children’s Commissioner Colleen Gwynne, parliamentary documents show.

title.children: Failed prosecution of Colleen Gwynne revealed to have cost more than $260,000

image.altText: A black and white image of a number of people sitting and standing on a long boat in the ocean

items.synopsis: Researchers from Flinders University publish findings suggesting the art depicts ships from the Maluku Islands in Indonesia, which could have reached Australian shores prior to colonisation.

title.children: Archaeologists link 'fighting' boats in Arnhem Land rock art with pre-colonial trade to Australia's north

image.altText: A senior aboriginal man wearing a bright green collared shirt.

items.synopsis: Fifty "peacemakers" from remote communities across the Northern Territory have met to discuss effective conflict resolution strategies in a bid to reduce civil unrest.

title.children: NT leaders strive for peaceful conflict resolution in remote communities

image.altText: Ukrainian soldiers use a launcher with US Javelin missiles during military exercises in Donetsk region.

items.synopsis: Western tanks are arriving while Russia dusts off 70-year-old museum pieces. But although Ukraine has the quality, experts say Moscow has the upper hand in quantity and warn "there's no such thing as a tank that can't be killed".

title.children: Western tanks will 'almost certainly' be destroyed. What does it take to knock out a tank?

image.altText: Kevin McCarthy wears an open-neck shirt and jacket as he speaks at a microphone

items.synopsis: US House Speaker Kevin McCarthy and President Joe Biden race to strike a deal to limit federal spending and resolve the looming debt crisis ahead of a June 5 deadline.

title.children: 'Historic reductions in spending': Biden and McCarthy reach in-principle agreement on debt ceiling

image.altText: A brick of cocaine on a shelf next to aluminium foil

items.synopsis: A security guard helps police make a 120-kilogram cocaine bust at a port in south-east Sydney, leading to the arrest of two Greek nationals.

title.children: Two men charged after 120kg of cocaine found in Port Botany shipping container

image.altText: Illustration of a woman with black bob holding sign saying "permanent visa" in front of a sign saying Welcome to Australia

items.synopsis: If you're a migrant wanting to stay in Australia, you might hear about "Tia". She operates in messaging apps and few have met her in person, though many have handed over tens of thousands of dollars in the hope of getting an Australian visa.

title.children: If you're after an Australian visa and prepared to pay, you might hear about this woman

image.altText: A crashed car being towed.

items.synopsis: It's been confirmed that four teenagers who were in a fatal crash yesterday near Hamilton were all students at the same school. Four teenagers died and another was critically injured.

title.children: School community in Victoria's west reeling after 'horrendous' fatal crash

image.altText: A composite graphic showing an artificial intelligence robot and a generic picture of a doctor f

items.synopsis: While there is huge potential for artificial intelligence to revolutionise health care, Australia's peak medical association calls for national guidelines to control the use of ChatGPT.

title.children: 'Cease immediately': Doctors forbidden from using artificial intelligence amid patient confidentiality concerns

image.altText: Woman wearing cream coloured top holding a mug.

items.synopsis: For the first time, Canberra charities are finding full-time public servants, nurses, teachers and police officers are regularly needing their help to make ends meet.

title.children: 'I'll go without food': Krystal has a full-time public service job, but the rising cost of living has her turning to charities

image.altText: Information Commissioner Peter Shoyer sits in an office.

items.synopsis: Peter Shoyer says he offered only "brief advice" to the NT government regarding a privacy breach of medical files before the incident was "managed in-house" and subsequently kept secret.

title.children: NT information commissioner seeks to distance himself from privacy breach

image.altText: Director dressed in black jacket stands behind her Palme d'Or award, smiling. Crowd of photographers behind her.

items.synopsis: Justine Triet sharply denounces the way the French government has "shockingly denied" protests against the highly contested pension reform.

title.children: France's Justine Triet becomes third female director to win top prize at Cannes, criticises French government in speech

image.altText: Brody Mihocek pumps his first as he runs away from the goals

items.synopsis: The Magpies will prove a massive test for the Kangaroos under interim coach Brett Ratten, while the Tigers host the Power as Sunday footy continues. Follow our live AFL ScoreCentre for all the scores, stats and results.

title.children: AFL live: League-leading Magpies take on Roos under the roof as Tigers clash with Power

image.altText: Tina Turner sitting down for an interview in new documentary

items.synopsis: When Tina Turner opened up in 1981 about being a victim of domestic violence, speaking publicly about the issue was unheard of. However, her bravery had an enormous impact on others.

title.children: 'A strong, courageous woman': Tina Turner's role in opening up domestic violence conversation

image.altText: the burns pout shell of a building after a fire

items.synopsis: A 12-year-old boy is now also assisting detectives with their inquiries, police say he was inside the building, along with two other teens who handed themselves in late on Thursday.

title.children: Third boy assists detectives with investigation into Sydney blaze that destroyed historic building

image.altText: Job ads in a newspaper.

items.synopsis: If this is the end of 'tight' labour markets, let's appreciate what we've achieved, writes Gareth Hutchens.

title.children: Will we miss 'tight' labour markets? These six graphs tell the story of Australia's post-pandemic jobs market

image.altText: Two men wearing camouflage gear holding a camera and microphone with soldiers in background.

items.synopsis: As the ABC's East Asia correspondent, Bill Birtles has covered geopolitical tensions, the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic and at one point made headlines himself.

title.children: 'I could never have imagined how my posting would end': Birtles reflects on eight years reporting on China

image.altText: A woman in a black dress and a purple headscarf sitting with a laptop on her lap

items.synopsis: I work as the social media producer for Q+A and have seen the things some of you write about Stan Grant. If you knew what your relatives and close friends are saying behind the comfort of their screen, you would be horrified, writes Neryssa Azlan.

title.children: I work on Q+A's social media and I see racist abuse every day. You might be shocked by who's writing it

image.altText: a man arrested by police at the airport

items.synopsis: Federal police work with Turkish authorities to arrest Guy Habkouk, who they allege was behind the shipment of almost 350 kilograms of heroin in December 2020.

title.children: Turkish officials deport alleged mastermind behind one of Australia's biggest heroin hauls

image.altText: A composite image of Taylor Swift, Britney Spears and Billie Eilish.

items.synopsis: Psychologist Tim Byron and musicologist Jadey O’Regan recorded five popular hooks to test your memory. Can you guess the song without vocals?

title.children: When it comes to catchy songs, there's a reason why these ones get you, hook, line and sinker

image.altText: a woman wearing glasses looking at the camera with her arms crossed

items.synopsis: Festival director Gill Minervini is experienced in running big events, but the large scale of Sydney Vivid is something else for the self-confessed "festival junkie".

title.children: The woman behind Australia's biggest light festival wants people to have fun — and think a little along the way

image.altText: A grid of images of women and text under the words #bodypositivity.

items.synopsis: A new study from the University of New South Wales finds viewing just small amounts of content showing diverse body types on social media can improve body satisfaction in young women.

title.children: How a small amount of body positivity is having a major impact on young women

image.altText: An Indigenous Australian man in an Aboriginal flag shirt holds a fist up to his heart, and looks at the camera.

items.synopsis: Tasmanian playwright Nathan Maynard is using the safe space of the theatre to examine the fraught issue of who can call themselves Aboriginal, in his play At What Cost?

title.children: Who gets to say who is and isn't Aboriginal? Powerful play grapples with big questions

image.altText: Black and white photo of a group of well-dressed black and white people posing formally for the camera

items.synopsis: More than half a century ago, Australians were asked to head to the polls in a referendum to recognise Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people as part of the population and allow the federal government to make laws for them.

title.children: Families of 1967 campaigners reflect on Indigenous rights on referendum anniversary

image.altText: A graphic of a red up arrow next to a percentage sign, overlaid on a street view of a row of houses.

items.synopsis: Around half of fixed rate borrowers whose low-rate home loans are expiring over the next two years are planning to leave their current lender, but it's those customers who can't that might prove a bigger problem for the banks, new research finds.

title.children: Banks face 'mortgage prisoners' and escapees as the reality of soaring rates bites

image.altText: Ukrainian soldiers use a launcher with US Javelin missiles during military exercises in Donetsk region.

items.synopsis: Western tanks are arriving while Russia dusts off 70-year-old museum pieces. But although Ukraine has the quality, experts say Moscow has the upper hand in quantity and warn "there's no such thing as a tank that can't be killed".

title.children: Western tanks will 'almost certainly' be destroyed. What does it take to knock out a tank?

image.altText: A man stands on a beach.

items.synopsis: The bestselling writer says he was offered "good money" to turn his novel The Messenger into a film or TV series in the US. But he decided it should be made in Australia.

title.children: Author Markus Zusak knocked back Hollywood to make The Messenger TV series in Australia

image.altText: Parked cars on either side of a quiet road through a town with hills in the background

items.synopsis: Victoria's regional residents are going to extraordinary lengths to fight big-name liquor companies that want to set up shop in their picture-perfect communities.

title.children: As one picturesque Victorian community loses its fight against a liquor giant, another town's fight begins

image.altText: A small fluffy Northern Bettong is being released into nature

items.synopsis: It's not a quokka or bilby, and there's a reason you've probably never seen a Northern Bettong in the flesh. Here's how Queenslanders are saving the native creature.

title.children: First of its kind: Queensland wildlife sanctuary built to save cute creatures at risk of extinction

image.altText: Two servicemen fire an anti-aircraft gun, with fire seen coming out.

items.synopsis: Ukraine has struck oil pipeline installations deep inside Russia with a series of drone attacks, according to Russian media

title.children: Drone attacks damage Russian oil pipeline installations as Russia claims to have downed UK-supplied missiles

image.altText: This photograph shows an exterior view of the German embassy in Moscow.

items.synopsis: Hundreds of civil servants and local employees working for German institutions in Russia will need to leave the country or lose their jobs in the coming days following an order by Moscow.

title.children: Russia to expel hundreds of German employees by start of June

image.altText: Vehicles are left stranded on a hillside after the road ahead is covered with snow

items.synopsis: Police say the avalanche hit as the tribe crossed a mountainous area in northern Pakistan, adding that harsh weather conditions hampered the rescue operation.

title.children: Avalanche kills 11 people from nomadic tribe in Pakistan

image.altText: Everton fans support the team and protest the board, owner Farhad Moshiri and chairman Bill Kenwright, Jordan Pickford

items.synopsis: Everton have been a Premier League ever-present and a significant figure in the formation and history of English football. But years of mismanagement and a season of derision and division have them 90 minutes from disaster.

title.children: A giant of English football is on the brink. This is how Everton got here, and where they're headed next

image.altText: A man in black holds a pole walking on a wire above the harbour and Opera House.

items.synopsis: The French performer felt no fear as he balanced above the Sydney Harbour Bridge — until he spotted what the police were doing out of the corner of his eye.

title.children: Fifty years since his highwire act above Sydney, Philippe Petit reveals 'stupid' police intervention
